review.title: Feature Weighting for Improving Document Image Retrieval System Performance
review.abstract: Feature weighting is a technique used to approximate the optimal degree of influence of individual features. This paper presents a feature weighting method for Document Image Retrieval System (DIRS) based on keyword spotting. In this method, we weight the feature using coefficient of multiple correlations. Coefficient of multiple correlations can be used to describe the synthesized effects and correlation of each feature. The aim of this paper is to show that feature weighting increases the performance of DIRS. After applying the feature weighting method to DIRS the average precision is 93.23% and average recall become 98.66% respectively

metadata.title: Feature Weighting for Improving Document Image Retrieval System Performance

sections.text: This paper presents a method of feature weighting for the Document Image Retrieval System (DIRS) based on keyword spotting, in which the feature is weighted by the coefficient of multiple correlations, which can be used to describe the synthesized effects and correlations of each feature. The aim of this paper is to show that feature weighting increases the performance of DIRS. After applying the feature weighting method to DIRS, the average accuracy is 93.23% and the average memory is 98.66%, respectively. Keywords: Information Retrieval, Indexing, Document Image, Feature Weighting.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: Document Image Retrieval System (DIRS) based on keyword spotting performs the matching directly in the image data, bypassing OCR and using word images as a query. In DIRS [1], no weights are assigned to the extracted features and the weights for all features are one, although some features have a greater effect on the query. Feature weighting is a feature weighting algorithm that determines weights, not just rankings [14]. Frequently used feature weighting methods only take into account the distribution of a feature in the documents and do not take into account class information for the weights of the features. Several methods have been reported for feature weighting based on term frequency (TF) [16], reverse document frequency (IDF) [17]. In [15], a framework for integrating multiple, heterogeneous feature spaces into the kmeans clustering algorithm describes a method of weighting in this document.

sections.heading: 2. Related Works
sections.text: In recent years, researchers have made a number of attempts to retrieve document images using word image. A detailed overview of the retrieval of document images up to 1997 can be found in Doermann [7]. An overview of the retrieval system of document images is presented in [10]. Attempts were made to perform word-level image comparisons and queries for printed documents [3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 9, 11, 12, 13]. Leydier et al [8] used DIP techniques to create a sample dictionary for each document and then perform word comparisons by selecting the gradient angle feature and an appropriate algorithm. In previous work on Word Shape Coding, Li [5] used an alternative technique and a combination of feature descriptors for keyword weathering without the use of OCR. In [4] a novel, differential word image algorithm is designed for the use of word variants for word morphological descriptions in a language.

sections.heading: 6. Experimenting the Proposed System
sections.text: In our experiments, the evaluation of the proposed system is based on 100 document images. The database of documents was automatically created from various digital text documents. In order to calculate the accuracy and retrieval values, 30 searches were performed using random words. sections.heading: 7. Conclusions
sections.text: In this paper we present the method of feature weighting in the document retrieval system. The proposed method uses the coefficient of several correlations for the weighting of each attribute. The purpose of this method is to increase the performance of the DIRS. The results obtained indicate that the proposed method is capable of particularly increasing the performance of the DIRS in terms of average memory and average precision.
